No, Europe is plenty of languages who are older than us, speaking the oldest Balkan language (within Greek) doesn't mean speaking the oldest in Europe. First of all, Albanian is an Indo-European language, genetics don't matter in linguistics, the Indo-European family originated in an area between Ukraine and Kazakhstan, then it spread in several dialects, which diverged more and more until they became separate languages, the Balkans were inhabited by several populations in the ancient times (Greeks, Illyrians, Paeonians, Thracians, Dacians, Phrygians, Dacians, etc.), one of these languages (except for Greek and Phrygian) might have gave the birth of Albanian, non-Balkan origin theories were discarded due to the lack of proofs, while there are many proofs about the Balkan origin of Albanian. But Greeks, Illyrians, Dacians, and so on, were not the original languages of the Balkans, being IE they migrated there in the prehistoric times, before the existence of civilization and writing systems, the Balkans and Europe (except from the area occupied by the early Proto-Indo-Europeans) was inhabited by mysterious populations we don't know, the only residue of that time is Basque, a language that doesn't have relatives, direct or indirect (unlike Albanian whic is a distant relative of Slavic, Germanic, Iranian, Italic, Celtic, and other IE groups). So, is Albanian the oldest living language in Europe? NO, IS JUST NATIONALISM BULLSHIT, IS NONSENSE Who's the oldest language in Europe then? Basque is, because it is what remained of the old pre-Indo-European languages in Europe (not get confused with Proto-Indo-European).
